oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Reverend James Morris Lawson, Jr., Nashville, Tennessee, 1960 March 01
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A photograph of Reverend James Morris Lawson, Jr., at First Baptist Church, 8th Avenue North, Nashville, Tennessee, March 1, 1960. Having served as field representative for the Fellowship of Reconciliation, Reverend Lawson was the key organizer and instructor in passive resistance techniques and nonviolent strategies for the Nashville Student Movement. While leading the Nashville Movement, Reverend Lawson stated that it was his hope that the sit-in demonstrations in Nashville would "end segregation and evil social injustice." Reverend Lawson was also projects director for the National Christian Leadership Council, which was organized by Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. in 1958. It was under the encouragement of Dr. King that James Lawson came to Nashville to help organize a nonviolent movement. Forms part of the Nashville Banner Archives. 1 photograph : b & w ; 8 x 10 in.
